verse: The ·Lord spoke his word [word of the Lord came] to me in the ninth year [since King Jehoiachin’s exile (1:2)], in the tenth month, on the tenth day of the month [January 15, 588 bc]. He said:
“·Human [Son of man; 2:1], write down ·today’s date [the name of this day], this very ·date [day]. The king of Babylon has ·surrounded [laid siege to] Jerusalem this very day.
And tell a ·story [parable] to the ·people who refuse to obey me [rebellious house]. Say to them: ‘This is what the Lord God says:
“‘This is what the Lord God says:
“‘So this is what the Lord God says:

“‘By your ·sinful action [lewdness; obscenity] you have become ·unclean [defiled; ritually]]. I wanted to cleanse you, but you are still unclean. You will never be cleansed from your sin until my ·anger [wrath] against you is ·carried out [satisfied; exhausted].

“‘I, the Lord, have spoken. The time has come for me to act. I will not ·hold back punishment [relent] or feel pity or ·change my mind [or be sorry]. I will judge you by your ways and actions, says the Lord God.’”
Then the ·Lord spoke his word [word of the Lord came] to me, saying:

“·Human [Son of man; 2:1], I am going to take ·your wife from you, the woman you look at with love [the delight of your eyes]. ·She will die suddenly […with a stroke/blow/jolt], but you must not ·be sad [lament] or ·cry loudly [weep] for her or shed any tears.

Groan silently; do not ·cry loudly [mourn] for the dead. ·Tie [Wrap; Bind] on your turban [normally taken off for mourning], and put your sandals on your feet. Do not cover your ·face [lower face; or mustache], and do not eat the ·food people eat when they are sad about a death [or food brought by others; bread of men].”
So I spoke to the people in the morning, and my wife died in the evening. The next morning I did as I had been commanded.
Then the people asked me, “·Tell [Won’t you tell…?] us, what do the things you are doing mean for us?”
Then I said to them, “The ·Lord spoke his word [word of the Lord came] to me. He said,

‘Say to the ·people [house] of Israel, This is what the Lord God says: I am going to ·dishonor [desecrate; profane; ritually] my ·Temple [sanctuary]. ·You are proud of the strength it gives you […the pride of your power] and ·you look at it with love and tenderness […the delight of your eyes and the desire of your soul]. But your sons and daughters that you left behind in Jerusalem will fall dead by the sword.

When that happens, you will act as I have: you will not cover your ·face [lower face; or mustache], and you will not eat the ·food people eat when they are sad about a death [or food brought by others; bread of men].

Your turbans will stay on your heads, and your sandals on your feet. You will not ·cry loudly [mourn or weep], but you will rot away ·in your sins [or because of your sins/iniquities] and groan to each other.
So Ezekiel is to be an ·example [sign; object lesson] for you. You will do all the same things he did. When all this happens, you will know that I am the Lord God.’

“And as for you, ·human [son of man; 2:1], this is how it will be. I will take away ·the Temple that gives them strength and joy, that makes them proud [their stronghold, their joy, and glory]. ·They look at it with love, and it makes them happy […the delight of their eyes and the desire of their soul; v. 21]. And I will take away their sons and daughters also.
·At that time [On that day] a ·person who escapes [fugitive] will come to you with information for you to hear.
·At that time [On that day] your mouth will be opened. You will speak and be silent no more. So you will be a sign for them, and they will know that I am the Lord.”
